column1: Weil der Stadt is a town of about 19
column2: 000 inhabitants in the Stuttgart Region of the German state of Baden-Württemberg. It is about 30 km (19 mi) west of Stuttgart city centre
column3: in the valley of the River Würm
column4: and is often called the "Gate to the Black Forest".

column1: The name Weil derives from from the Latin word villa
column2: an estate or manor. The suffix die Stadt (the town) was added to distinguish Weil from various nearby villages of the same name
column3: such as Weil im Dorf and Weil im Schönbuch. The modern name is unusual in that it contains the dative article der rather than the nominative article die. This quirk arose because place names typically come after prepositions that govern the dative case in German
column4: such as in or aus. The Roman origins of the town are immortalized in its coat of arms

column1: The village of Wile was first mentioned in 1075
column2: and described as the property of the famous abbey of Hirsau. Weil der Stadt became a Free Imperial City in the 13th century
column3: but had existed for centuries before as an important trading place.

column1: The city was completely destroyed during the Thirty Years' War in 1648 but was subsequently rebuilt
column2: and is still dominated by buildings from this period. The city's fortifications have survived largely intact

column1: Weil der Stadt is best known as the birthplace of the astronomer Johannes Kepler (1571–1630)
column2: and it bears the unofficial title of Keplerstadt
column3: or Kepler town. Another famous son is the Protestant reformer Johannes Brenz (1499–1570). Due to its surroundings and attractive cityscape
column4: dominated by the church steeple of St. Peter and Paul
column5: Weil der Stadt is a popular destination for excursions in the Stuttgart region.

column1: Weil der Stadt is a stronghold of traditional carnival
column2: which is celebrated with a parade in the city centre. In contrast to the carnival in the Rhineland
column3: the carnival in Weil der Stadt
column6: shared by various towns in southwestern Germany and Switzerland.

column1: Weil der Stadt escaped destruction in World War II when a French artillery barrage was called off in honour of it being Kepler's birthplace.
